carve somebody/something ↔ up.translatio: to divide land, a company etc into smaller parts and share it between people – used especially to show disapproval
The Ottoman Empire was carved up by Britain and France after World War I.
The two companies are attempting to carve up a large slice of America’s publishing industry between them.
to drive past a car and then suddenly move in front of it so that you are too close
an arrangement between two or more people, governments etc by which they divide something among themselves even though this is wrong
